body: The dialog looks like it assumes that you should be starting some kernel. I think it also needs to be easy to open a notebook with no kernel at all, when you just don't have the relevant kernel installed. E.g. if I open an Haskell notebook, none of the kernels available are a suitable substitute.
@takluyver I think working well without a kernel is not in scope for 3.0. Code everywhere assumes there is a running kernel, and I don't think we can remove that reliably in our current timeframe.
That said, I can add a 'cancel' button that enters the 'Dead kernel' state, indicating that "things are broken", which is accurate.
Yes, something like that. I would call it something more precise like 'Don't start a kernel' instead of 'Cancel'.

An alternative to project_name would be putting language name and version in the kernelspec. I know we moved that information out of the kernelspec because language info kept growing, but it may make sense to have one or two keys of redundant info in the kernelspec to address this compatibility issue.
project_name doesn't provide any mechanism for a notebook to 'require' Python 3. I'm not sure we need to support that, but we might consider including that info.
Forgot to ping @fperez and @ellisonbg for the missing kernel behavior
ping, Travis failure (I didn't look at the log)
Yup, I'll finish it up after we've talked about it tomorrow.

Trying to understand exactly what this does...

When I originally proposed the "project_name" idea, I was thinking of it as a human readable name that we could use in the notebook UI (such as an on hover to give more information about the kernel) to help users understand more about the kernel. This would allow us to keep the main visible name short and focused on the language, while allowing a user to dig deeper into the actual project providing that language.

Sounds like you are using the project name in a different way to handle certain types of errors? Can you describe a bit more of the motivation?

I wasn't addressing the text on hover at all, I'm not sure how or why that would differ from display_name. This is purely meant to address the issue that the necessarily 1:1 _name_ of the kernelspec doesn't address the 1:many reality of notebook:kernel compatibility.

For example: I have 6 IPython kernels right now, for various distributions and debug use cases. If I create a notebook and associate it with my 'python3-debug' kernel, you should still be able to open it, as long as you have _any_ IPython kernel.

An alternative could be to copy some subset of the language_info we get from the kernel_info request back into the kernelspec (where it started), and use that to identify compatibility.

We could also punt on this question entirely, and only keep the dialog used when no _identical_ kernel can be found. That would mean that any user running Python 2 would get a dialog saying "I couldn't find a Python 3 kernel" whenever they open an example notebook.

Ahh, Ok thanks for the explanation. Now I understand this PR much better.

Hmm, it seems like tackling the whole kernel compatibility thing in an automated way is a bit crazy. While there are definitely some obvious cases where there is a clear answer, there are others where it will be difficult. Here is one proposal:
- If a kernel for a notebook doesn't exist, open the notebook and let the user pick which installed kernel they want to use. If they don't have any kernel then they can pick the best one and at least edit the notebook and not run code.
- Just use the project name as I described above - for human usage in on hover events to learn more about a kernel so if there are 2 kernels with the display name "Python 2" they can see i) the name of the kernel and ii) the name of the project.

Another idea would be for us to implement and provide a "null" kernel that does nothing, but allows a users to edit a notebook. But it would at least have all of the right keyboard events hooks up to make cell execution do nothing in a good way.

> and provide a "null" kernel that does nothing, but allows a users to edit a notebook

You mean a in-browser js kernel ?
Originally I wasn't thinking a JS based kernel, but that probably makes the most sense. It is a different way of handling the "no kernel" case that may lead to simpler code.

I think leaving it in the dead-kernel state makes the most sense for 3.0. Writing a new dummy kernel doesn't seem reasonable at this point, and most of the severe UI problems when the kernel is dead or missing have been addressed.

+1

From the dev meeting:
- We will do something like this, but with a field called language_name instead of project_name.
- First it will check for an exact match with the kernel name
- If there isn't a match, it will find all kernels with matching language name
  - If there's only one, start that
  - If there's more than one, prompt the user to select from those that match
  - If there are no matches, prompt the user to select from any available kernels, with a prominent option to not start a kernel.
@minrk is this ready for review?

Updated per the dev meeting, this now uses a `language` field, instead of `project_name`, which is `python` for any Python kernel.
1. if kernelspec name matches, use it (no change from master)
2. if exactly one kernel's language matches, use it (no dialog)
3. otherwise, prompt with selection from:
   - matches, if more than one
   - all kernels, if no matches

A "No appropriate kernel" button allows the user to use the notebook without starting a kernel.

Should be ready to go.

The "No Appropriate Kernel" seem more like a statement than a action to do for me. 
If you find a better sentence, like "Continue without kernel" or whatever, that would be good. 
Thoughts ?

Maybe this has been discussed already, but is there a plan to display a warning in the second case (no match for kernelspec name but exactly one kernel's language matches), maybe in the terminal that lauched the notebook server?

> Maybe this has been discussed already, but is there a plan to display a warning in the second case (no match for kernelspec name but exactly one kernel's language matches), maybe in the terminal that lauched the notebook server?

Would be complex to do in the terminal.

In the notification area maybe ?

I agree on the "Continue without kernel" idea.

@Carreau I added a notification message, but it's immediately dismissed because there are other notifications that follow it as part of kernel startup. Any way to get a message that will stick without being clobbered by subsequent messages? If not, I'd be inclined to leave out the notification, for now.
Button renamed to "Continue without kernel".

> @Carreau I added a notification message, but it's immediately dismissed because there are other notifications that follow it as part of kernel startup. Any way to get a message that will stick without being clobbered by subsequent messages? If not, I'd be inclined to leave out the notification, for now.

I think that should be possible, let me check.

There use to be a one shot notification widget (which click on it would destroy), but it was not used so remove. 

Do you want me to redo it with a convenience methods. Something like `notification_area.one_shot_warning(message)` ?
@Carreau create a widget, display the message, and destroy on dismiss? I think I can handle that.
